awd_abstract_narration:
It is well known that protons and neutrons are made from constituents, called quarks and gluons, which make up the substructure of protons and neutrons. The goal of this project is to make measurements of the position and momentum distributions of the quarks and build a three-dimensional map of quarks in the nuclear medium. This knowledge provides the basis of our understanding of nuclear matter in terms of the dynamics of their internal constituents. Using this information, theoretical models show how the constituent parts of the proton and neutron can be used to build up their fundamental intrinsic properties, such as their overall size and quantum mechanical spin.  This award will support two undergraduate students each year as they learn both hardware and software skills that will prepare them for careers in the STEM workforce. 

 This project engages the PI and Duquesne University's undergraduate students in research aimed at the study of  parton distributions using semi-inclusive production of pions and kaons with CLAS12 at Jefferson Lab. Data taking and analysis for unpolarized and polarized deuterium and hydrogen targets are part of this project.  In addition, the PI will lead the efforts in software development, characterization, reconstruction, and calibration as the analysis coordinator of a second hybrid ring imaging Cherenkov detector (RICH) which is under construction.  This detector will identify in the momentum range of 3 to 8 GeV/c.  Undergraduates play an integral part in this project, which provides them with opportunities to further their training and education outside of the classroom. This will include:  gaining experience in the design, assembly, and testing of modern particle physics detectors, high tech fast electronics, and scientific data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Measurements with identified target fragmentation hadrons can provide important information on several topics in hadronic physics: the nucleon tomography and quark orbital momentum, accessible through the study of the Generalized Parton Distributions (GPDs) and the Transverse Momentum dependent parton Distribution functions (TMDs), the quark hadronization in the nuclear medium, the hadron spectroscopy, the search for exotic mesons and the topic of this proposal: the parton distributions and the fragmentation functions. This project engaged the PI and Duquesne undergraduate students in research aiming to study the partonic distributions using semi-inclusive production of protons, kaons and pions in CLAS12 of Hall-B at Jefferson Lab. Data taking and Physics analysis for unpolarized and polarized deuterium and hydrogen targets are part of this project. In addition, the PI lead the efforts in software development, characterization, reconstruction and calibrations of two hybrid Ring Imaging Cherenkov detectors (RICH) that are being used for charged hadron identification. Students participated in hardware and electronics projects at Jefferson Lab or at INFN laboratories and in software development and data analysis projects, locally at Duquesne. Several Physics and instrumentation peer reviewed papers along with presentations in national and international conferences by the PI and her students resulted from this work.  

Knowledge of Parton Distribution Functions (PDFs) represents the basis of our understanding of hadronic matter in terms of its fundamental degrees of freedom. The results of this research project will lead to critical improvements in several areas of spin physics including in the strangeness sector. The ensuing dramatic improvement in the knowledge of fragmentation functions will be an important ingredient in the global analysis of the nucleon structure from semi-inclusive Deep-Inelastic-Scattering and pp collision data. Thus, contributing in a unique way to the challenge of understanding how partons build up all intrinsic properties of the nucleon, in particular how they share the nucleon spin. This is one of the main goals of the upgraded 12 GeV CEBAF accelerator at JLab and future Ion Collider (EIC). Final results will be disseminated in peer-reviewed scientific journals and considerable coverage in more broad-based literature, such as dailies and periodicals at an international level. The results will serve as reference input to other experiments in Nuclear and high energy Physics.

Besides advancing fundamental science, education of students was a central component of this proposed project. We had outstanding opportunities to contribute to this goal as well as a very strong record of accomplishment in this area. We were committed to providing meaningful and useful research experiences to our students. Duquesne undergraduates played an important role in this project, which provided them with opportunities to further their training and education outside the classroom. This included; gaining experience in the design, high tech fast electronics and scientific data analysis. As with previous students who worked with the PI, these students had the chance to present their work to the university community and at the American Physical Society’s Division of Nuclear Physics (APS/DNP) meetings, Gordon conference and at the National Black Physicists Annual meetings.  35% of the undergraduate students in the physics department at Duquesne are female and the PI is playing a role model in her research, she particularly encouraging the engagements of these students in STEM-related fields. In addition, two African American students were supported by this grant and the PI provided them with the best training and guidance to achieve their dream to become part of the STEM workforce.
